title: 103_hr2326
content: The Act titled "Bankruptcy Amendments of 1993" includes amendments. The Bankruptcy Amendments of 1993 include changes to Chapter 13 eligibility criteria and automatic stay provisions in the United States Code. Debtor qualifications are now debts less than $1,000,000, and the automatic stay can be extended with consent or for compelling circumstances. The Bankruptcy Amendments of 1993 amended Section 522 of title 11, United States Code, defining "household goods" and specifying exemptions such as works of art, electronic entertainment equipment, jewelry, and antiques purchased by the debtor. Section 522(d)(3) and Section 522(f)(2) of title 11, United States Code are amended to remove references to "household furnishings" and "appliances." Additionally, Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code is amended to include exceptions to discharge related to fraud and false representations. The amendment includes changes to the language regarding intent to deceive, increasing the fine amount to $100, extending the time limit to 60 days, and addressing injury resulting from reckless disregard. Additionally, a modification to the effect of discharge is made for debtors not represented by an attorney during negotiations. (g) Section 1322(b)(2) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to modify the rights of secured claims, excluding claims on the debtor's principal residence unless they were undersecured at the time of attachment. (h) Section 1322(c) of title 11, United States Code, is amended. The amendments to title 11 of the United States Code limit plan payments to a maximum of 5 years. Confirmation hearings for plan modifications must be objected to within 5 days of notice to the creditor. The hearing on confirmation of the plan must be held after the 10-day period following the first meeting of creditors. Section 1326(c) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include "timely" after "payments". The Administrative Office of the United States Courts compiles and releases statistical information annually on bankruptcy cases, including debtors' liabilities, assets, income, expenses, debts discharged, payments to creditors, and time between filing and first payment under a confirmed plan. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICATION OF AMENDMENTS. This Act and its amendments will take effect on the enactment date, except for cases under title 11 of the United States Code initiated before that date.
